content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: There are many graph traversal/BFS kind of puzzles on CG, but the additional constraint of wire rating here makes this one interesting enough.
I ran my BFS backwards (from E to S) to simplify my code, but most likely different approach would also work.
Modification requests from other reviewers were all dealt with, so the puzzle looks OK.

* Please move "Wires are bidirectional" from the Constraints section to the Goal section. This defines a core mechanic rather than a constraint on the input.
* Please change the constraint "1 <= [[N]] <= 100" to "2 <= [[N]] <= 100". N cannot be 1 since S and E are distinct.
* Please change the constraint "0 <= [[M]] <= 100" to "1 <= [[M]] <= 100". M cannot be 0 since every node is connected to at least one other node.
* Consider explicitly stating "[[S]] â‰  [[E]]" in the Constraints section for better clarity.

Thank you.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Ok for me!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Instructive BFS puzzle :)
Are the nodes always labelled 0 to N-1?

Goal
* Please change [[i + T]] to [[i]] + [[T]].

* Please clarify what exactly constitutes a step: is it defined as electricity moving from one point (power source or bulb) to another point (bulb or star)?

* Consider adding a small example with a step-by-step walkthrough to make the mechanics easier to understand.

Input
* Please add "space-separated" before "integers" in all three descriptions.

* Next M lines: Please format "M" and the second instances of "A", "B" and "T" as [[variables]].

* The input description may be confusing because everything, including the power source and the star, is referred to as a "bulb". While this works technically, it is inconsistent with the story. Please adjust the wording if possible to make the roles clearer.

Output
* Please format "IMPOSSIBLE" as a {{constant}} instead of a [[variable]].

Constraints
* Please format all variables.

* Please reorder the constraints so they follow the same order as in the Input section.

* Please add constraints for [[A]] and [[B]].

* Please change all of 1000, 5000 and 1000 to 100.

Cases
* Test/Validator 2: The case [[S]] = [[E]] feels odd from a story perspective.

* Validator 11: There are two wires connecting bulbs 2 and 5.

* If not already done, please ensure that each test and its validator cover the same scenario, and that the cases adequately covers most scenarios including some edge cases (if applicable).

Thanks.

Thank you for the detailed feedback! I've addressed all points:

Goal/Statement:
- Changed [[i + T]] to [[i]] + [[T]]
- Clarified that a step is when electricity moves from one node to an adjacent node
- Added a step-by-step example showing how the mechanic works (valid path vs invalid path with T=1)

Input:
- Added "space-separated" before "integers" in all three descriptions
- Formatted [[M]], [[A]], [[B]], and [[T]] as variables in "Next [[M]] lines"
- Changed terminology from "bulbs" to "nodes" (power source, star, and N-2 bulbs in between) to better match the story

Output:
- Changed [[IMPOSSIBLE]] to {{IMPOSSIBLE}}

Constraints:
- Formatted all variables with [[brackets]]
- Reordered to match Input section: N, M, S, E, A, B, T
- Added constraints for [[A]] and [[B]]: 0 <= [[A]], [[B]] < [[N]]
- Changed all limits from 1000/5000 to 100

Cases:
- Removed Test/Validator 2 (S=E case) - now 10 pairs total
- Fixed Validator 10 (was 11): replaced duplicate edge 2 5 1 with 5 8 1
- Verified all test/validator pairs cover the same scenario with different values to prevent hardcoding
Practically - yes.

Thank you. Updated:
* Moved to description
* 1 < N <= 100
* 0 < M <= 100
* Added to constraints.
Thanks for clarifying. Could you make this explicit in the problem description please?
Done.
Please format "N" as a [[variable]]. Thanks.
Thanks. Updated.
Oops, the three "T"s in the example are [[variables]] too. Could you please format those too? Thanks.
Updated.

Thanks for going through all the feedback! I've reviewed the updated version and have a few additional comments:

Goal
* Consider changing "A step is when electricity moves from one node to an adjacent node." to "A step occurs when electricity moves along a wire from one node to another." This removes the undefined term "adjacent" and makes the meaning clearer.

* You may use <<text>> (bold format) instead of **text**.

Cases
* Validator 11: The duplication is still present. Perhaps the latest changes didn't save properly?

* Please renumber the cases.

* Test/Validator 6 and Test/Validator 9 appear to cover the same scenario. If that's indeed the case, please revise Test/Validator 9 so that there are multiple valid paths from the power source to the star, but on every path the fuse blows somewhere in the middle at step 5 or later.

* At the moment, each case contains at most three (usually only two) distinct [[T]] values. In particular, many cases start with [[T]] = 1, which causes paths to fail almost immediately and exercises very little of the BFS logic. It'd be helpful to improve the case design by introducing a wider variety of [[T]] values, and including failures that occur at different points along a path in different cases (this also applies to the *possible* cases).

Thanks.

Thank you for the follow-up feedback! All points addressed:

> Consider changing "A step is when electricity moves from one node to an adjacent node." to "A step occurs when electricity moves along a wire from one node to another."

Changed as suggested.

> You may use <<text>> (bold format) instead of **text**.

Changed **Important:** and **Example:** to <<Important:>> and <<Example:>>.

> Validator 10: The duplication is still present. Perhaps the latest changes didn't save properly?

Fixed and tested locally, but forgot to update in CG.

> Please renumber the cases.

Renumbered and titled all the cases.

> Test/Validator 5 and Test/Validator 9 appear to cover the same scenario. If that's indeed the case, please revise Test/Validator 9 so that there are multiple valid paths from the power source to the star, but on every path the fuse blows somewhere in the middle at step 5 or later.

Redesigned Test/Validator 9: now has two parallel paths from source to star, and on EVERY path a fuse blows mid-way (at step 5 or later). Both paths fail with T=3 and T=4 at different points, making the answer IMPOSSIBLE.

> At the moment, each case contains at most three (usually only two) distinct [[T]] values. In particular, many cases start with [[T]] = 1, which causes paths to fail almost immediately and exercises very little of the BFS logic. It'd be helpful to improve the case design by introducing a wider variety of [[T]] values, and including failures that occur at different points along a path in different cases (this also applies to the *possible* cases).

Added variety across all tests:
- Valid edges now use varied T values (7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 14, 15, 16, etc.)
- Test 5/Validator 5 redesigned as single-path mid-failure cases (T=5 at step 5, T=3 at step 3)
- Test 9/Validator 9 have failures at step 5+ with T=3 and T=4
- Test 10 uses T values 26-35 for the Hamiltonian path
- T=1 is only used where geometrically necessary (blocking paths of length 1)

Good, the cases look more robust now!

It's more difficult for me to go through the cases by hand now, so we may have to wait for reviewers who attempt your puzzle to see if they find anything else. For my part, I've gone through Test/Validator 6 by hand. Please correct me if my understanding is off.

* Test 6: Wheel Hub Blocked: Valid paths include 0 -> 1 -> 2 -> 3 and 0 -> 5 -> 4 -> 3, which have equal length. To distinguish these, I would suggest changing [[E]] to 4, but then the shortest valid path becomes length 2, which is the same as the invalid path via node 6. I would therefore further suggest modifying the input so that the central node is #7, the two valid paths are 0 -> 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 and 0 -> 6 -> 5 -> 4, and the invalid path becomes 0 -> 7 -> 4.

* Validator 6: We use the same logic here, but we can simply change [[E]] to 6 (and the expected output) to achieve the desired effect.

* Apply similar logic to the other cases: try to ensure that different paths within a case have different lengths. This helps verify that a solution finds the correct path rather than another path of equal length.

* Do any cases cover the scenario where all fuses blow at the same time: at the final step? If not, consider creating a pair of cases for this if possible. At the same time, it may be best not to have too many IMPOSSIBLE cases. You could either merge some impossible paths into possible cases (which still ensuring that the solver evaluates the impossible paths), or add additional pairs of cases (e.g. with many valid paths to choose from) so that the overall proportion of impossible cases remains less than half.

Thanks again.

> * Test 6: Wheel Hub Blocked: Valid paths include ...
Yep. Redesigned the test:
- Invalid: 0->7->4 (length 2, T=1)
- Valid short: 0->6->5->4 (length 3)
- Valid long: 0->1->2->3->4 (length 4)
- This ensures correct algorithm finds length 3, not just any valid path

> * Validator 6: We use the same logic here, but we can simply change [[E]] to 6 (and the expected output) to achieve the desired effect.
E changed from 5 to 6
- Clockwise: 0->1->2->3->4->5->6 (length 6)
- Counter-clockwise: 0->9->8->7->6 (length 4) - correct answer
- Via hub: 0->10->6 (length 2, T=1 invalid)

> * Apply similar logic to the other cases...
Updated the tests. Now:
1. Simple Path; N=3; M=2; Simple BFS works=Yes; Multiple paths - No
2. Disconnected; N=4; M=2; Simple BFS works=Yes; Multiple paths - N/A
3. Triangle + Alt; N=4; M=5; Simple BFS works=No; Multiple paths - Yes (2)
4. Hexagon; N=6; M=7; Simple BFS works=No; Multiple paths - Yes (2)
5. Mid-failure Bypass; N=8; M=9; Simple BFS works=No; Multiple paths - Yes (2)
6. Hub Blocked; N=8; M=9; Simple BFS works=No; Multiple paths - Yes (2)
7. Shortcut + Alt; N=9; M=10; Simple BFS works=No; Multiple paths - Yes (2)
8. Grid Traversal; N=9; M=10; Simple BFS works=Yes; Multiple paths - Yes (3+)
9. Fuses at Final; N=4; M=4; Simple BFS works=No; Multiple paths - N/A
10. Circle Complete; N=14; M=80; Simple BFS works=No; Multiple paths - Yes (2)
11. Hamiltonian 10x10; N=100; M=100; Simple BFS works=No; Multiple paths - No

> * Do any cases cover the scenario where all fuses blow at the same time: at the final step? ...
Kind of now: test 9 - all paths burn exactly at arrival.

>  At the same time, it may be best not to have too many IMPOSSIBLE cases.
Agree. Reduced the number of impossible solutions. Now test stats are like
- IMPOSSIBLE: 2/11 = 18%
- Single valid path: 2/9 = 22% (Tests 1, 11)
- Multiple valid paths: 7/9 = 78%
- Naive BFS correct: 3/11 = 27% (Tests 1, 2, 8)
- Max N: 100
- Max M: 100

Also, added test with maximal N and M values.

Just a list of the key test features:
1. Simple Path - Basic test, algorithm works normally
2. Disconnected - Edge case: no path at all
3. Triangle + Alt - Shortest path (T=1) burns, two alternative paths
4. Hexagon Diagonal - Diagonal blocked, two perimeter paths
5. Mid-failure Bypass - Main path breaks mid-way, two bypasses available
6. Hub Blocked - Central hub unusable, must go around edge (2 paths)
7. Shortcut + Alt - Short path blocked, two long paths valid
8. Grid Traversal - Grid navigation, multiple equivalent paths
9. Fuses at Final Step - ALL paths burn exactly at arrival
10. Circle Complete - Dense graph (M=80), must use perimeter
11. Hamiltonian 10x10 - Max constraints (N=100, M=100), snake path

Well done. That's a fairly comprehensive set of test cases. Here are my comments on the latest version:

Constraints
* Please add the following constraint:
Every node is connected to at least one other node.

Cases
* Test 8: Nodes 3 and 6 are missing. Please add wires connecting these nodes.

* For testing purpose, I slightly modified the example in the Goal section so that the input is:
3 2
0 2
0 1 2
1 2 1

I'd expect the answer to be 2, but your solution code outputs IMPOSSIBLE. Have I misunderstood anything?

* Assuming my understanding is correct, I'd suggest replacing the last test and the last validator with cases generated by this code, where [[S]] â‰  0 and the wires along valid paths are in randomised order: https://pastebin.com/n2UsACuy

Thanks.

Thanks for the review.

> * Please add the following constraint:
Added.

> * Test 8: Nodes 3 and 6 are missing. Please add wires connecting these nodes.
Updated them.

> I'd expect the answer to be 2, but your solution code outputs IMPOSSIBLE. Have I misunderstood anything?
No, you are right. It is was a bug in my solution (extra +1) and I missed the edge case (facepalm). Fixed it now and updated the tests accordingly.

> * Assuming my understanding is correct, I'd suggest replacing the last test ...
Added a new test but had to change the proposed generator a little: made generation predictable (by providing a seed) and made N configurable. Also, with N=100, it was generating M>100 which is against the constraints. So I reduced it to 96 (thasuch an N gives M==100).

Good catch! I forgot the constraint on [[M]] when I wrote the case generator ðŸ˜›

Two minor fixes:

Constraints
* I don't see the suggested constraint added yet.

Cases
* Validator 9: Node 4 is missing.

That should be all of my comments for now. Since I haven't written a solution myself, we'll have to see if any additional issues come up as others attempt the puzzle.

Thanks.

> * I don't see the suggested constraint added yet.
Ah. Thank you. CG gives me 524 periodically and I have to copy/paste changes from scratch. This time I missed the constraints update. :-( Fixed it now.

> * Validator 9: Node 4 is missing.
Added an edge to the node 4.
I know. I've run into the 524 error here many times myself. But hey, that won't stop us from helping Santa, right? ðŸ˜‰

100% :-D

Is it OK for me to move the task to the Ready state?
Moved. Worst case, I can change it back.
